descript.abstract: The parcel feature class is a polygon feature class representing the individual parcels for Butte County, California, 2009, which was derived from assessor map pages in digital and hardcopy formats. All new parcels are entered from assessor CAD pages registered to orthorectified imagery.
descript.purpose: For use with GIS software. This layer is designed as a Tax Parcel product. This information is intended for cartographic use, general spatial analysis and as a spatial index to Land related information. It is not intended for site specific analysis.

idinfo.useconst: Refer to the License Agreement for Butte County Digital Geographic Data Sets. Data are licensed to Princeton University-affiliated persons only.

cntaddr.address: Map and Geospatial Information Center, Lewis Library, Princeton University

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.0 (Build 6001) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.0.3348

dataqual.logic: The data set is topologically structured polygon data.
dataqual.complete: All areas of Butte County and all incorporated areas have been mapped. Completeness is 100%.

horizpa.horizpar: The relative horizontal positional accuracy for the information used to develop the original tax parcel data is estimated at +/- 20 feet (NMAS 1:12000) in urban areas and +/- 40 feet (NMAS 1:24000) in rural areas. With the implementation of the GPS centerline positional accuracy is higher in areas.

citeinfo.origin: Butte County Department of Development Services
citeinfo.title: Butte County Parcels

pubinfo.publish: Butte County Department of Development Services

srcinfo.srccontr: Assessor’s digital DWG files and hardcopy scans.

BCAG contracted with the consulting firm Quad Knopf Engineering, Inc., to take BCDDS’s countywide parcel file and improve its spatial accuracy by rectifying it to BCAG’s highly accurate centerline road file. Also, base was brought up-to-date by adding missing parcels.

procstep.procdesc: The process for the parcel file cleaning was made up of four (4) phases that resulted in a more accurate parcel layer. The four phases consisted of: 1) importing or digitizing page; 2) cleaning; 3) registering; 4) implementing. The first phase in the adjustment process began with the importing of the Assessor CAD pages. The County Assessor maintains its pages as AutoCAD drawings (.dwg files). The prevailing factor in using the Assessors’ CAD drawings is to maintain the parcel pages’ scale and geometric accuracy. Each CAD drawing received from the Assessors’ Office was generated using Coordinate Geometry (COGO), which allows for accurate segment lengths and scale. Relevant layers from each CAD drawing are delineated and imported into an ArcInfo coverage. Important layers consist of lots, easements, roads, and parcels. If the CAD page was not available from the Assessor then the page needed to be manually digitized. Each paper parcel page was scanned at 300 dpi and converted to a vector format using heads-up digitizing. This work was subcontracted with ETS Digital in Chico. In order for the GIC to make the appropriate adjustments, all Assessor parcel pages need to be in digital format with parcel boundary lines digitized as a single vector layer in DWG file format. Thus, approximately 1,200 assessor parcel pages needed to be scanned, and the vector lines representing parcel boundaries needed to be extracted and saved as a DWG file. ETS scanned each Assessor parcel page, and digitized only the parcel boundary vector lines (no rivers, easements, etc), and were saved as a single DWG file. The parcel boundary vector lines were the only lines to be digitized as part of this contract. Page breakdown: Chico 303 pages, Oroville 176 pages, Paradise 376 pages, Butte County and remaining areas 371. Unfortunately the CAD parcel page drawings’ topology (connectivity, area definition, and contiguity) from either the Assessor or ETS sometimes contained errors that would not allow the newly created Arc coverage to work correctly with the ArcInfo GIS master coverage. The most frequent example of this was lines/arcs that cross one another without actually connecting at the point of intersection. To correct this discrepancy, the clean command was used. This command: corrects geometric coordinate errors, assembles arcs (lines) into polygons and creates feature attribute information (shape/area/length) for each polygon or arc. A two-foot tolerance was used for this process. Essentially the end point of any arc/line was connected or snapped to another arc that was within a two-foot radius. After the clean operation was performed, a GIS technician manually rechecked each newly created parcel page coverage for any topological errors. If there were any errors found, the technician used ArcEdit to correct any remaining errors. Following the import and clean procedures was the registration phase. During this stage, the newly created and cleaned Arc coverages were registered using ArcGIS. Registration changes the Arc coverage coordinates using a projective transformation based on a set of control points. This process basically designated a real world location for the parcel page coverage. The real world location was referenced to an ortho-rectified aerial photo of the area and control points were derived. Control points are specific locations on the photo such as fence lines, intersections, and sidewalks. Once the parcel page coverage had been moved to its’ relative real world location, the rotate function was used to properly align the new page to the county master GIS coverage and aerial photo. Since the original AutoCAD drawing file was created with the appropriate scale, the coverage did not require any further scaling. After the newly created parcel page coverage had been registered, it was ready to be implemented. The implementation stage consisted of weaving the registered parcel pages into one master GIS coverage for the entire county within ArcEdit. The technician used his/her best judgment when sorting out discrepancies among pages. In addition to creating a master coverage that consisted of arcs/lines and nodes/points of connection, label points were created or updated as well.
Parcel linework was digitized from hardcopy assessor?s maps and controlled to US Census Bureau TIGER files.

Processed file using ‘adjust’ arcinfo command. Command rubbersheets file based on centerline control. In an effort to make the parcel file current with the Butte County Assessor’s Parcel Books, the consultant also added approximately 4,500 parcels to the parcel file that had been missing from the County’s original parcel file.

attr.attrdef: Pool Code - A code designating the type of pool installed on the parcel.
Transfer Document Number - The number assigned by the County Clerk Recorder's Office to the most recent title transfer document.
Use Code - Land Use Code
Other Value - The assessed value assigned to non-structural improvement component of the parcel by the County Assessor's office.
Assessor's parcel number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Building Class - The codified value for quality class of the structure on the parcel. The codification is based on the California State Board of Equalization rules for appraisal.
Has Septic - A Boolean value assigned to the parcel indicating that it has a septic system on site.
Garage Size - The size of the garage measured in square feet.
i. Unit Size - The size of the unit measured in square feet.
Timber Preserve - Also known as Timberland Production Zone created by Timberland Productivity Act of 1982.
Homeowner Exemption - A Boolean value assigned the parcel indicating that the owner is receiving the Homeowner's Exemption currently valued at $7000 in taxable value reduction.
Tax Amount - The annual amount of taxes assessed against the parcel. This value does not include additional supplemental taxes that might be assessed against the parcel.
County name.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Unique number assigned to county by Census.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: House number.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Street direction.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Street name.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Street suffix.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Full street address.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Situs city name.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Situs ZIP code.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Tax Rate - Tax Rate Area (TRA) assigned to the parcel.
Additional owners.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Owner's mailing address.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Owner city, state, and ZIP.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Longitude of point-in-parcel.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Latitude of point-in-parcel.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Longitude of lower left parcel bounding box.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Latitude of lower left parcel bounding box.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Longitude of upper right parcel bounding box.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Latitude of upper right parcel bounding box.
attr.attrdefs: NPDP Standard Extended Attribute Table Format

attr.attrdef: Total Value - The sum total of the Land, Improvement, and the Other value components of the parcel.
Number of Full Bathrooms - The number of full bathrooms contained within in the unit.
Lot Square Feet - The area of the parcel measured in square feet.
Legal Description - The legal description of the parcel.
Lot Acres - The area of the parcel measured in acres.
Taxability Code - The code used to designate how a property is to be taxed.
Feature geometry.
Assessment Year - The assessment year for the values assigned to the parcel.
Primary Land Owner - First owner listed on the deed.
Agriculture Preserve - Property identified under the California Land Conservation Act (CLCA) of 1965 (also known as The Williamson Act.)
Number of Fireplaces - The number of fireplaces contained within the unit.
Land Value - The assessed value assigned to the land component of the parcel by the County Assessor's office.
Improvement Value - The assessed value assigned to the structural improvement component of the parcel by the County Assessor's office.
Number of Half Bathrooms - The number of half bathrooms contained within the unit.
Situs Unit Number - The unit number portion of the street address assigned to the situs.
Number of Bedrooms - The number of bedrooms in the unit.
Year Built - The year that the building structure was completed.
Has Well - A Boolean value assigned to the parcel indicating that it has a well on site.
Number of Units - Number of residential units on the parcel.
Has Sewer - A Boolean value assigned to the parcel indicating that it has sewer hookup to a municipal sewer system.
Number of Buildings - Number of buildings on the parcel. Each building may contain multiple units of multiple types.
Building Size - The size of the building measured in square feet.
Effective Year - The equivalent year of the building structure after any remodeling has been completed.
Feature geometry.

distinfo.distliab: BCAG member jurisdictions may distribute the GIS base data according to their own discretion. Non-member jurisdictions are permitted to use the GIS base data for internal business purposes only, and cannot sell, transfer, license, sublicense, disclose or allow access to the digital data to any third party without express written permission from BCAG. However, if any manipulation and/or processing of data are required to fulfill a request, an entity may charge the cost incurred for those services. BCAG does not guarantee the accuracy or quality of the digital data. The information is taken ?AS IS? without any representations or implied warranties as to the fitness for a particular purpose or otherwise. It is further understood that any and all rights, claims, causes of action or other recourse against BCAG for injuries or damages of any type, whether direct, indirect, incidental, consequential or otherwise, resulting from any error or omission in the data or in any programming used to obtain the data, or in any manner arising out of or related to the data retrieved herein, are forever waived. It is agreed that BCAG shall not be liable for any liability, claim, loss, damage, injury or expense of any kind caused or alleged to be caused, directly or indirectly, by the inadequacy of data obtained from BCAG, by any deficiency of BCAG or user systems, by any delay or failure to provide service, or by any other interruption, disruption or loss to operations.

stdorder.fees: A fee will be levied to non-BCAG member agencies for monthly, quarterly, bi-annual and annual updates. The costs for receiving the updates are detailed in BCAG?s GIS base data subscription plan.
stdorder.ordering: Contact Butte County Association of Governments.
